text: yeah so i am currently in texas but i spent many years in the bay area and i was really lucky to work with manish
agarwala at stanford and bjorn hartman over at berkeley and so i'm happy to be back even if it's virtually this time um
but today i'll talk about the work i've done just for the past two years on making videos accessible
[Music] so today people use digital platforms to communicate and increasingly we're
changing the way we're communicating so video formats like explainer videos how-to demonstrations and travel vlogs
are starting to replace their text counterparts and the scale of video production and
consumption today is massive so just on youtube alone people watch one billion
hours a video per day and upload 730 000 hours of video every day
in addition it's not just viral videos so in a survey asked 12 000 people to
name their main reason for watching youtube videos two of the top three reasons were actually related to seeking information
they wanted to learn new things or to dig in into their interests and of course youtube isn't even
counting all of the live video like zoom or short videos uh like gifs and tick
tocks or videos we use for social communication um like facetime for instance
so there's a lot of ways that we can choose to communicate information and when we pick one like video some
audience members will benefit and others might be left out so let's use video as
an example so video is great if you are going to watch
and listen to the video all the way through so for instance if a doctor sends me a physical therapy exercises
rather than a text description this might be really useful um the video will capture my intention and it might
provide this rich spatial and temporal detail so i can see how he's moving his shoulders
in addition it promotes recall so maybe i'll actually do my physical therapy exercise more often because i'll remember it
but say you don't intend to watch a video all the way through instead maybe you missed uh you missed
this talk or another and you just want to see one part of it well referencing and reviewing a video
is quite difficult due to this partially to this timeline based interface and it's even worse if video is a core
part of your everyday work uh like for researchers or film producers
so i spent my phd with manisha and bjorn exploring how we can make videos useful when people needed to use it for
reference or review so in my postdoc i wondered about the other part of this assumption what if
you're not actually able to see the visual content or hear the audio content
even though you plan to consume the entire video so currently uh videos communicate
information both auditorially and visually and so some videos like
this genre of tasty videos that are silent faking videos set to music would
be completely inaccessible if you didn't have access to the visual content of this in
the video and this is really concerning as more and more of our educational um and
training content for work is moving to these video formats and finally if you don't have the
appropriate background or even regional knowledge there's other reasons it can be difficult to understand the video
even if you plan to watch and listen to it all the way through so for instance if i'm a brand new uh crocheting i
perhaps shouldn't start with a more advanced crochet video because it would be difficult to interpret the visual
content so media is most useful when it supports
the goals accessibility needs and context of the users and audience members actually might
require different representations of the idea in order to best
get that information so for instance if i'm watching and listening all the way through video is great but also you
could imagine maybe more immersive formats like ar and vr in
in addition if i was going to reference and review maybe a textbook or an online article might provide me more structure
to you to find text or to look through chapters and sections
so there's this principle in the universal design guidelines for learning that you should provide multiple means
of representation and there's not one means of media or representation that's optimal for all
of course if you're an instructor and you're trying to provide many forms of the same idea you could imagine that
would be a lot of work so my research is about creating systems that make it way easier to create
communication that's more useful for everyone and a key idea throughout my work that you'll see in this accessibility work as well is to try to
combine the benefits of multiple types of representation so like text and uh
video for instance so now i've motivated a little bit about why i'm interested in video
um but i'll touch now on why video accessibility is important so when i think about accessibility i like to come
i've heard several arguments and i here's some of my favorites so uh for
i think the first reasons i think about are personal so most people will experience a disability either you have one today or
you will be lucky enough to live long enough into the future that you'll have one in the future so it's in my own best interest to
consider accessibility now in addition we can be personally responsible for creating disability and
this might sound surprising um but a really classic thought experiment that i like is pretend that tomorrow everyone
sprouted wings and i was the only person that didn't spray wings this really wouldn't be a problem until
they moved like my favorite coffee shop into the sky or all my friends start hanging out there um so disability isn't
just about impairment or the activities that you can't do but the ways that it
limits your participation um in in activities so for instance hanging out with my friends or visiting a coffee
shop and so when we create media or new forms like ar and vr intangibles it's really
important to think about who we are lifting up in the sky and who we might be uh leaving on the ground and also i think there's more
people who experience disability that i might have initially realized so in america one in four people live
with a disability today and i'm going to talk a lot about uh non-visual accessibility in this talk so i'll
mention that a million americans are blind and 11.4 million have another visual impairment um and this isn't even
accounting for users who might not want to look at their screen maybe they have light sensitivity or they lost their
reading glasses yesterday so how do we make videos accessible currently
well to make videos accessible um professionals to people with visual impairments
professionals create audio descriptions or narrations of the important visual content that overl avoid overlapping the
audio content and i will call out that this is slightly different than closed captions
closed captions um transcribe the speech and sound and make the audio accessible for people for instance who are deaf or
hard of hearing and all of this accessibility editing uh takes place after the video has been
produced so just really quick let me show you an example of an audio description if you
haven't seen one before this will go by a little fast so audio descriptions um the narrator
will talk first and the audio describer will talk second it takes a village to maintain and
operate a place like mount rainier national park what role would you play
who will be the future of mount rainier national park job titles appear including trail crew archaeologist
engineer climbing ranger and more future rangers children wear uniforms for different park jobs linnea i'm a
future archaeologist all right so i picked this one because um it's one of the rare examples of
audio description that isn't for a film or a tv show that's where they occur most frequently but important things to
see here is that the author omitted a lot of visual details like linnaeus safety best and several of the job
titles and they also had to offset the descriptions uh to make everything fit within the time provided and so all of
this is really challenging especially for film and movies where you have quick dialogue that you kind of have to fit um
as much as you can about the visuals in between so the first project i worked on as part
of my postdoc was to see if there was a way to make um audio descriptions easier to create
and the first thing i wanted to do was understand why audio description is why audio descriptions are challenging to
create so i talked to seven audio description professionals this included producers audio engineers writers and
teachers to learn how they create audio descriptions and two things key things they mentioned is that timing is really
challenging there's always more that you want to say about the visuals than time you have to say it and also the wording
is important so because of uh audio description happens at the end of the video production
process there might be other stakeholders like marketers or um the uh
the videos original scripter who care about how the content is described so to create audio descriptions
professionals uh outlined the following steps they identified gaps in the speech and
marked it on the timeline and they typically transcribed via text where the gaps were they didn't describe the
visual content in each gap and then uh they would record the descriptions of the visual content but
oftentimes they would overlap so there's much more to say than time to say it and then they have to spend a lot of time uh
editing the descriptions to fit and this could take over 10 times the length of the original video um and so this is a
really tedious process you've done the creative part of describing the video and then you have to edit it down
so the goal of this project was to let people create audio descriptions efficiently and the
key idea was to basically do optimization to jointly shorten the text and lengthen the source
audio to fit everything that we could so i'll show you the tool we built called rescribe
using rescribe you could insert an input video it would automatically visualize speech
and audio gaps along the timeline and it would also transcribe the video and show the gaps
in the transcript so authors could easily navigate to the gaps using either the timeline of the
transcript so there an author jumped to a gap
and then the author can describe the video by playing and pausing it so here the author types get title gabby's guide
to ojai what's gotta be cooking um rescribed and interactively updates the timeline the transcript so that you get
a sense immediately of about how much time you have left and so then uh another description's a
bright a montage of bright footage from ojai for instance
after you've scripted your descriptions um then you need to record them one really cool thing about rescribe is you
only need to record your descriptions once um and the editing happens automatically we used human recorded
descriptions because prior studies had shown that blind and visually impaired watchers preferred
human descriptions to automatic ones for now so here's an example of someone recording
their descriptions shots of lavender in a farmer's market
red flowers against a white house and blue sky and after you've recorded all of your
descriptions you can click create and rescribe is going to automatically shorten the descriptions and move them
around to fit in the time provided
and then you can go ahead and listen to your results title gabby's guide to ojai
a montage from ojai shots in a farmers market red flowers
a courtyard and a pool gabby bikes along a path close up of french fries
gabby drinks sangria gabby and thomas sit on a couch hey guys
so if you don't like any of your descriptions you can edit them after the fact or um lock them in place if you
don't want the algorithm to change them so resky rendered three types of descriptions it could render extended
inline descriptions so these pause the audio to play back all of the description of the video and this is
really disruptive to the flow but you can fit as much information as you want if you add a pause
next were inline descriptions so these shortened the descriptions greatly to fit them in the time provided so for
instance um a montage of from ojai was automatically shortened from a montage
of bright footage from ojai and this is what you just heard so that changed the length of the
description and it also adjusted their start time but finally because we already had this in an optimization algorithm we
kind of explored could we actually extend the underlying source audio to fit in uh more of the text
description so in this case uh we are able to fit in more text so shots uh we're able to
preserve shots of lavender at a farmers market and we do this by extending the underlying audio by finding um similar
beats so this one is going to break the sync with the video visually but you can
also try to listen for the loop to see if you can hear uh where we're repeating the the music
gabby's guide to ojai a montage from ojai shots of lavender in a farmer's market
red flowers against a white house and blue sky a courtyard and a pool gabby bikes along
a path close up of tater tots and french fries gabby drinks sangria
gabby and thomas sit on a couch [Music] hey guys
so i'll cover a few of the algorithmic methods that power rescribe so first rescribe identifies the speech and
silence um in the video by first transcribing it and then using a cnn uh based detection to to find speech and
silence uh next the author describes the video and rescribe automatically aligns the
script and the record and the recording and finally and this is the core part of rescribe it
automatically edited the descriptions it could shorten them delete them adjust the timing or extend the underlying
audio i'll just try i'll try to breathe uh breeze through a little briefly on how
we did it but just to give you an idea um for each description we generated a bunch of candidates but of course only
one of these candidates can be included in the final audio and we had about two to three hundred to pick from
so we scored each candidate description on a number of things so informativeness was this description likely to be
important for the rest of the video uh coherence is this likely to be grammatically correct that's not exactly
what it is but sort of close so that would catch things like gabby r back which is not a great description we also
looked at edit quality so each time you cut the audio that might impact uh the final quality and finally the
placement so this is this going to overlap with other speech or not and we basically solve this uh using an
optimization algorithm so we evaluated rescry with three user groups so first we were curious uh about
could novice audio describers um create descriptions more effectively we also wondered if blind audience members would
prefer our inline and extended inline descriptions to uh the just pausing the video type and
we finally wanted to find out what professional subscribers thought so novice authors were able to author
descriptions in the same amount of time that had far less um overlapping audio
instances which would make it quite difficult to hear both the description and the video blind audience members really like the
extended inline descriptions uh and they they liked uh the inline descriptions because they were concise and used and
standard with what they're used to hearing on the other hand the extend extended descriptions that pause the video were
really a last resort one interesting thing to me was that they mentioned they would like to watch extended inline descriptions most of the
times when um they are alone so they thought maybe if i'm watching with a sighted audience member um it might
disrupt the visual content but in the future you could imagine research that makes those uh those visual pauses a
little bit uh less abrupt and then finally our interviews with professional describers were really
interesting so professionals were highly suspect that ai could help do their job
which is quite hard um any easier and so we found that they liked that this preserve the creative
aspects of their work while shortening the uh tedious part of the process they had really great ideas for future
automation too so one thing that was really repetitive about their job was describing um
was for instance just describing the same thing over and over again so if they wanted a system to reapply their
existing descriptions in the future so some takeaways from rescribe are that it made it easier to create high quality
descriptions so instead of trying to describe everything automatically we used human descriptions and just sort of
changed them a little bit to fit them in time we also revealed a new type of audio description that hadn't existed before
and was preferred by blind audience members and users we found that users had varying description needs uh based
on their context so the fact that rescribe gave them three options allowed them this ability to customize the
descriptions they were receiving so
if we think about how we should make videos accessible um you know rescribe gave audience members sort of three
options that they could pick between but videos don't always have these nice
pauses in the video that can allow you to insert this description so one thing we worked on was
interactive audio descriptions in videos where there's constant speaking could we give the
blind user more access to description on demand
so this project about uh about presentation accessibility and we focused on presentations because they're

of it so we wanted to provide blind learners access immediately to the content that wasn't described but also
access to that content within the context of the entire slide so for instance on this slide the speaker
described everything but attainable but if the blind user just listened to the word attainable it might be a little bit
confusing so we also put it in context of the full slide which was extracted automatically
so so what we found also is that at first um in some of our pilot uses people
didn't really uh try to query for more information unless the presenter referenced it uh so in this version of

students should be able to accomplish this learning and demonstrate it in the way laid out in the outcome in the time frame available
extra content on slide heading level five slide six undescribed regions list

the uh system let the user know that there was undescribed regions on the slide and the user was navigating i

and so when we compared this slideshow interface that it that surfaced uh the
moments that were undescribed and when we compared it to slides and video so just the slides in the video side by
side what we found is that people spent more time with the slides and video but got the same
score on on a little quiz for both we also found that using our system
people read less redundant content and listen to the description closer to the
time it was mentioned so some users are actually able to beat the rest of the audience to hearing the joke
and then we found as i mentioned that people were reactive rather than proactive about getting more information
um unless there is an explicit queue mentioned by the presenter so most people just waited to hear if there was
undescribed content or not on a slide and then they were they would uh listen to hear more of the content
so from this project we learned that um just extracting the content from slides
uh was already quite helpful for people um and this is easy because uh ocr does
a really great job at detecting and transcribing the text on on visual slides
in addition we found it beneficial to jointly analyze the audio and visual content to identify these undescribed
regions that let people view a lot less redundant content between the narration
that they're hearing and the slides that they're reading with their screen reader and finally uh prompting people when
things weren't described so you know they might not know that that word attainable exists so letting people know
so that they can find it um let people seek more information as unless the presenter mentioned it they
might not know that there's more content there so both of these projects work with this
this constraint that the video has already been authored and published and there's nothing you can do
to it and it makes the problem a lot harder than it necessarily needs to be so in the next project we we broke this
assumption and we said hey what if we try to encourage authors to make their videos accessible from the start oh
and so in particular we looked at presentations again and we thought hey what if we could encourage
presenters to give narrations that were actually more descriptive of the content on the slides
so in this project called say it all we encourage presenters to create embedded descriptions or descriptions that are
present in the original video so first we wanted um and this was really inspired by uh our own experience
uh there's an accessibility conference where people would ask authors to describe their slides but perhaps they
would start with the best intentions and then eventually forget um and so and this is also you know our own
experience and you could remind an author a couple times but it it would be easy to just kind of go back into how
you're used to presenting the slides without describing all of the visual content so before we got started we wanted to
know do people just incidentally already describe their slides so we analyzed a bunch of videos across
ted talks seminars and classes about across a range of randomly sampled academic disciplines um and and we did
this to maintain a a variety of kind of preparation and production levels
and in general the answer was no so 72 of all of the slide elements in our data
set were not fully described and one thing that was surprising to me that was that ted talks which are highly produced
were particularly good at describing the text and particularly good bad at describing the images and so what i
found out when i looked into this a little bit further is that the ted talk guidelines actually say that you should
keep your text simple and make sure it matches your speech and on the other hand they tell presenters explicitly
not to describe their images because it might be seen as redundant so a key idea i took away from this is
that when you're asking people to describe the content on their slides the design of the pres the design of the
slides as well as the narration matter so uh
my next question was can we make people describe their slides if they're not doing it already
so we created a system called slideshow it provides both real-time feedback and
post-presentation feedback and the idea here is that we wanted to impact people's narrations as well as the
design of those slides so i'll share a quick example of the uh real-time
feedback provided by this tool and we imagine that the real-time feedback could be used for more casual
presentations or in rehearsal as you're trying to make your descriptions better so here's an example
so today's section is organized around two activities first we'll create a colorful circle brush and you'll see the
squiggly line pictured on the right with these rainbow circles so in this example on the presenter view
it's highlighted in green on the content that the presenter has already said after the presenter is done um so
presenters can either use this or turn it off but after they're done they can look at the post presentation feedback
uh the post presentation feedback on the right side basically shows presenters what they described and
people can try to raise their score pictured in green or red
to try to increase their coverage so they could raise their score by deleting excess text on the slide
by changing their script to add more of the description of the content and so they could get a higher coverage score
on their presentations
so in studying this project we wanted to know um could did this actually work if
we created these interfaces would people change their behavior and describe more of the slides so we studied we created a
study with people using their own slides with and without both types of our feedback
and what we found was yes so people describe more of their slide uh elements
using sayadaw's real time feedback and we looked at we looked at applying the feedback both first and second so uh
would they see the feedback first or would they see the feedback second what i expected is that after seeing the
feedback they would do uh on the first time they would do really great on the second half so so i expected that um
seeing the feedback first would impact that but in fact it did not uh which is not a great sign for um guidelines alone
working well to encourage people uh to give feedback on their slides we also found that using the post
presentation interface people identify 3.3 times more accessibility improvements with the presentation
interface as they did without it in particular um we found some of our
presenters plan to make changes for their upcoming talks so some of our tas actually mentioned they plan to remove
excess text on their ta slides we just

all of these projects made the assumption that each individual video needs to be accessible
but for this last project we're going to go back to the beginning of the talk when we're thinking about videos there's
actually tons and tons of them such that for any one task uh you might need just
one video um to to serve your purpose and you might not need every single video to be accessible
so here we look at video search and making it easier for blind and visually impaired users to surface accessible
videos so in this project um we looked primarily at uh at search tasks so for
instance if you search for a video like how to make chocolate chip cookies you're going to get many um partially
equivalent results and same thing for things like paper airplanes or top 10 places to visit in italy there
might not be much distinguishing uh which one you should pick so in prior work where we just described
each inaccessible video in this video in this work we're looking at can we surface the videos or act that actually
happen to already be more accessible than others so if you're thinking about what makes a video um more accessible than other
videos some things include perhaps it's narrated the entire way through so
people on a how-to task have described every step versus uh setting it to music
and so so we wanted to approach this from a user's perspective so we asked 12
people with visual impairments who regularly used youtube uh what they found made a video more or less
accessible and what we found is that um some of these we sort of expected so
just the presence of speech uh happening throughout a large part of the video you would guess that this video is more
accessible um but then things that people mentioned that were a little surprising was um so scene transitions
so if it's highly if there's a lot of scene transitions that prompts audio transitions like oh
you hear like a big crowd and then you hear um you know a city street and you're not sure what happened at those
transitions um so if a scene is very visually complex it's likely to not be
as accessible people also mentioned um undescribed visual references so that's like if i
say hey look at this thing on my slide you might wonder what thing on your slide if you're not able to see the
visual content so from these accessibility metrics that we identified in these interviews
we also asked people to rate a bunch of videos from one to seven um
on whether they thought the video was accessible or not because it was blind and visually impaired people rating these videos uh it was basically the
perceived accessibility so what might not be included in the score are unknown unknowns or things people didn't know
were there and so what we found is that uh five of these attributes contributed to people's
perceptions of accessibility with presence of speech being one of the most predictive qualities
so after we had this accessibility score and um these metrics we augmented each
video search results um with some information about how accessible it was likely to be
so we gave a summary um uh prediction score so this one's somewhat accessible
and it provided some of the information about how we got to that conclusion so 76 percent of the audio speech uh the
speech is descriptive but it has many visual references about three per minute uh etc
so we implemented this as a browser extension so that you could go on youtube and it would calculate these
metrics and actually show them to you in the search results we found out that using our tool people were able to do
video search tasks more efficiently so before they would just trial and error a bunch of videos until they found one
that was accessible um but with our tool they were able to um trial and error less videos before they
got to one they were interested in and so now bruce the student who led this project is looking at uh if these
findings actually play out in practice so when people have this browser extension installed for their everyday
use do we say do we see the same things hold
so this is um my work so far looking across a bright a broad range of video
accessibility and i'll share some of my takeaways from where i think this means we should go next
so the one thing that surprised me is that unlike captions that just transcribe the audio
audio descriptions are quite difficult because you're really summarizing all of the visual content there's just too much
to describe in time and so some things i found that were particularly important uh were that you
needed to know not only what was important to include in the summary but also how and when you wanted to describe
it because that could impact the flow of the video or it could have ruined a surprise if you if you describe things
too early in addition i learned that the the overlap between the audio content and
the visual content is key so as a person or a tool if if you are not
looking at both the audio and visual content you might not know that some things would be redundant if you were to
describe them in the video a third thing is that
what is important greatly depended on the audience and their context so in rescribe we heard about depending on the
other people that were watching with them they might want a bit different description but something i would call out is that it didn't come up in um in
this presentation so far is that people actually wanted very different things so even for film and movies where where
audio description is more present people did not agree on on what they would like to like to hear in it so for instance i
met a sci-fi fan um and for sci-fi tv there's basically really elaborate
costume design and setting design and the audio description guidelines had dictated that the costumes were rarely
described so in a show where the costumes were really important um this viewer was just totally missing out on
how costumes uh were changing over the season and kind of what they meant in terms of
the character's progression so in the future i think it would be really important to give people more
control over what is included in their descriptions and finally one way to do this might be
interactivity but it's a little tricky so people uh interactive descriptions can be really
great when you know you might be missing something but for unknown unknowns so when you don't know you're missing
something a good place to share those changes might be when the visuals change
so for instance say i said i thought that costumes were important maybe the system would alert
me every time a costume changed so i could optionally hear more about that costume
and second i think it's really important to con to consider accessibility at every stage
so there's a lot of opportunity both in video but in new media forums like ar and vr to uh consider how the accessible
experience might appear at the end and then finally um working on this
project there's tons of guidelines about how to do audio descriptions for film and media but very very few for user
generated media because um because audio descriptions are just rare and
quite difficult to produce currently so i think we need new guidelines especially for user generated media
types like vlogs um or short videos like gifs uh gifts that are one thing i did get to work on and try a couple formats
for and that was really fun also uh i think there's new audio descriptions already static right
now but in the future there's new interactive techniques that we can use to make these more effective
so this has been a part of my work um building human ai systems and in the
case of doing accessibility research i've used mostly ai and ml techniques

creating the correct wording for something might require uh you to have a knowledge of where the original video

uh content and some of these new user generated media um is an important question

um in terms of creating uh more accessible content and formats uh i think there's ways that we could improve
